articles.headline: The Road Ahead Turns Right
articles.snippet: The G.O.P. is expressing its intention to revisit issues like health care, financial regulation and tax cuts.
articles.abstract: The G.O.P. is expressing its intention to revisit issues like health care, financial regulation and tax cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Energized by their big victories in the midterm elections, Congressional Republican leaders wasted no time on Wednesday in putting President Obama and Democrats on notice: the days of single-party control are numbered and legislating in Washington is about to get a whole lot more complicated.

articles.headline: General Motors Can Fly Again for Stock Sale
articles.snippet: The federal government has approved the use of chartered aircraft to ferry managers on a “road show” for a public stock offering.
articles.abstract: The federal government has approved the use of chartered aircraft to ferry managers on a “road show” for a public stock offering.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors executives have been cleared for takeoff again.

articles.headline: Fed to Spend $600 Billion to Speed Up Recovery
articles.snippet: The Fed’s move is an effort to nurture a fragile recovery ahead of battles that will dominate politics over the next two years.
articles.abstract: The Fed’s move is an effort to nurture a fragile recovery ahead of battles that will dominate politics over the next two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, getting ahead of the battles that will dominate national politics over the next two years, moved Wednesday to jolt the economy into recovery with a bold but risky plan to pump $600 billion into the banking system.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Sewell Chan

articles.headline: G.O.P. Faces Choice in How to Oppose
articles.snippet: The new Republican House majority is facing a choice between cultural or intellectual dissent.
articles.abstract: The new Republican House majority is facing a choice between cultural or intellectual dissent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day after the election always dawns sunny and full of hope in Washington. From Representative John A. Boehner on down, Republicans talked on Wednesday about how open they were to working with the president (except, perhaps, for repealing that whole health care thing). Rand Paul, the next senator from Kentucky, said on MSNBC that his family was hoping to meet the Obama girls. You could almost see the two dads stretched out in front of the TV, sharing a laugh at “Phineas and Ferb.”

articles.headline: Ouster of Iowa Judges Sends Signal to Bench
articles.snippet: Proponents of an independent judiciary were alarmed at a vote to remove three Iowa justices who were part of a unanimous decision to allow gay marriage.
articles.abstract: Proponents of an independent judiciary were alarmed at a vote to remove three Iowa justices who were part of a unanimous decision to allow gay marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — An unprecedented vote to remove three Iowa Supreme Court justices who were part of the unanimous decision that legalized same-sex marriage in the state was celebrated by conservatives as a popular rebuke of judicial overreach, even as it alarmed proponents of an independent judiciary.

articles.headline: Fed Gets Aggressive After Months of Holding Back
articles.snippet: The Fed’s bond-buying plan carries risks, but over time the effects of its nonaction have proved to be the problem.
articles.abstract: The Fed’s bond-buying plan carries risks, but over time the effects of its nonaction have proved to be the problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the last year, there were three basic camps on what the Federal Reserve should be doing.

articles.headline: In Rubio, Some See Rise of ‘Great Right Hope’
articles.snippet: Senator-elect Marco Rubio of Florida has gone from no-name former state lawmaker to inspirational leader.
articles.abstract: Senator-elect Marco Rubio of Florida has gone from no-name former state lawmaker to inspirational leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  For many Tea Party conservatives, Hispanics, and young Americans frustrated with the national debt that baby boomers have saddled on their future, Marco Rubio’s victory in the Florida Senate race gave them an extra reason to celebrate.

articles.headline: Genentech Offers Secret Rebates for Eye Drug
articles.snippet: The rebates were used to promote the drug Lucentis even though another of the company’s options costs far less.
articles.abstract: The rebates were used to promote the drug Lucentis even though another of the company’s options costs far less.
articles.lead_paragraph: Genentech has begun offering secret rebates to eye doctors as an apparent inducement to get them to use more of the company’s expensive drug Lucentis rather than a less costly alternative.

articles.headline: Democrats Outrun by a 2-Year G.O.P. Comeback Plan
articles.snippet: The balance of power shifted in a campaign marked by Republican discipline, Democratic miscalculations and a new dynamic out of both parties’ control.
articles.abstract: The balance of power shifted in a campaign marked by Republican discipline, Democratic miscalculations and a new dynamic out of both parties’ control.
articles.lead_paragraph: The PowerPoint slides presented to House Republicans in January 2009 seemed incongruously optimistic at a time when the very word “hope” belonged to the newly ascendant Democrats and their incoming president, Barack Obama.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Kinect Pushes Users Into a Sweaty New Dimension
articles.snippet: The Kinect, which plugs into an Xbox, can project a digital version of you on screen while you shimmy, shake and play active games.
articles.abstract: The Kinect, which plugs into an Xbox, can project a digital version of you on screen while you shimmy, shake and play active games.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the money Microsoft has spent on failed efforts to design hardware, you could finance a trip to Mars.
